intro: Mulgedium armeniacum, commonly known as Armenian mulledium, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of the Caucasus. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers in umbels, typical of its family. It thrives in cool, moist environments and is often found in rocky or forested areas. Due to its ornamental value and historical use in traditional medicine, it is occasionally cultivated in botanical gardens.
